column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Diy_coref|
#Text=Description of the Prior Art
#Text=[0007] As of 2007, there are 33 million people infected with HIV/AIDS worldwide, of which over 70% live in third world countries.
#Text=An individual infected with HIV has on average several years before HIV matures into the AIDS virus.
#Text=Regardless of the stage of their infection, patients' lives could be dramatically improved and lengthened through treatment with the most effective antiviral drugs available.
#Text=However, in developing countries alone, there are 9.7 million patients in immediate need of treatment to stay alive, of which only 3 million receive medicine.
#Text=Effective antiviral drug treatment of HIV/AIDS is complicated.
#Text=Drugs are not effective unless taken in strict adherence to a time schedule.

#Text=Furthermore, like antibiotics, taking drugs partially or out of sequence results in a building resistance by the HIV/AIDS virus; hindering treatment of the patient and, if spread, strengthening the HIV/AIDS epidemic.

#Text=In a hypothetical treatment regime, a patient may take daily up to four different antiviral pills in addition to pain-killers, vitamins, and medicine for the treatment of Hepatitis; prevalent in those infected with HIV/AIDS.
#Text=[0008] Providing these effective treatments to individuals in third world countries is a complex and multi-variable problem.
#Text=However, whether pharmaceuticals are donated or purchased by relief organizations for patients, there remain barriers for getting treatment to those that need it.
#Text=Among these issues is the one I am trying to solve: illiteracy and more importantly the inability to tell time.

#Text=The majority of those infected with HIV/AIDS in third world countries cannot or do not have the means to tell time and therefore do not have the ability to take HIV/AIDS medication correctly or effectively.
#Text=For instance, in the sub-Saharan country of Chad, of the 105,000 women infected with HIV/AIDS, up to 84,000 have no means of correctly taking complex medical treatments because of illiteracy.

#Text=Two statistics make this problem so compelling: there are at least 22 million people in third world countries with HIV/AIDS, and nearly every third world country has a literacy rate less than 60 percent.
#Text=Statistically, that means at least 10 million people are unable to realistically be treated effectively for HIV/AIDS because they cannot tell time
#Text=[0009] The inventor first learned of this issue when speaking to Ugandan relief workers recently returned from providing services to impoverished farmers in Africa.
#Text=To their surprise, doctors informed them that drugs could be made available but that not enough patients lived within range of their clinic to make daily journeys for medicine practical.
#Text=The underlining issue was the simple fact that there existed no system for them to take their medication accurately, consistently, and independently.

#Text=[0010] Therefore, there is a need for a system that assists individuals who cannot tell time from a conventional watch in recognizing the occurrence of an event, such as a notification that it is time to take a medication.
